ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New paper on why modules evolve, and how to evolve modular artificial neural networks
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Martin, Thanks. Please see below. ... I m not denying there is a lot of sequence/temporal learning out there. I m just saying that most such problems are

Subject: Re: [neat] New paper on why modules evolve, and how to evolve modular artificial neural networks
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=FJcRhcMSoHJ2XZaVYaLwm-qUKRJdx9Vd_jGgWmK5gjdCR-sxsT21

Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Martin,

Thanks. Please see below. 

> thank you for your answer Jeff=
. I think the discussion here is very fruitful. Indeed I did forgot that yo=
u made a control experiment where geometry could not be exploited. 
> 
> > =
This discussion raises the larger question of whether you could have truly =
temporal problems that did not require spatially distinct processing stream=
s
> 
> Maybe I misunderstand here something, but a truly temporal problem w=
ould be any kind of sequence learning (e.g. navigation, episodic memories, =
motor skills)?! Learning of information that have a temporal order, compari=
ng sequences, recognizing sequences. The area that has been associated with=
 these kinds of tasks is the hippocampus with its areas dental gyrus, ca3 a=
nd ca1. Information are processed along those three areas but each area ret=
urns also feedback to the entorhinal cortex (which in turn connects to the =
cortex). The hippocampus has been implicated in many different functions (d=
epending on the species in which it is observed) but maybe common to all pr=
oblem domains of the species that have a hippocampus is the fact that it ha=
s something to do with sequence learning. 
> 
> 
I'm not denying there is a=
 lot of sequence/temporal learning out there. I'm just saying that most suc=
h problems are complex enough that they also have a lot of spatial parallel=
ism (such as the splitting of the information stream out to the different m=
odules you mention). I just have a hard time imagining a single-stream, com=
plex, processing machine that learns to do different tasks. But at this poi=
nt I'm just wildly speculating. If such a mental structure existed, would m=
odularity help? By definition, we've eliminated parallel modules. So modula=
rity would have to pay off in terms of a serial sequence of modules. It is =
interesting to think about whether/why modularity pays off in that case (an=
d if it pays off for that specific organism, or across evolutionary time). =


> Given the fact that the anatomy of the hippocampus is very well conserv=
ed across evolution it seems to me that the hippocampus is an excellent exa=
mple, that spatial properties of biological neural networks can also be exp=
loited to solve temporal problems. Its modular structure seems to play cruc=
ial role here.
> 
> For more see: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/168810=
79
> 
> > As such, even if our technique did not encourage modularity for s=
imple problems where no separate processing streams are required, it probab=
ly is still important for most (all?) complex problems. 
> 
> In this conte=
xt I was wondering whether it could be helpful to measure the ratio between=
 the current number of edges in a network and the number of edges that have=
 to be removed in order to have a modular network. Maybe, this ratio could =
help to provide an analytical solution for the question how likely it is th=
at modularity emerges in larger networks. 
> 
> 
What would that number tel=
l you? How close you are to mutating to a modular network at any given gene=
ration?

-Jeff


> Best,
> Martin
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_68C39339-5A6E-479C-BA7C-9DCFA507A949

"> </span>



    <div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>thank you for your answer J=
eff. I think the discussion here is very fruitful. Indeed I did forgot that=
 you made a control experiment where geometry could not be exploited. <br>
=
<br>> This discussion raises the larger question of whether you could ha=
ve truly temporal problems that did not require spatially distinct processi=
ng streams<br>
<br>
Maybe I misunderstand here something, but a truly tempo=
ral problem would be any kind of sequence learning (e.g. navigation, episod=
ic memories, motor skills)?! Learning of information that have a temporal o=
rder, comparing sequences, recognizing sequences. The area that has been as=
sociated with these kinds of tasks is the hippocampus with its areas dental=
 gyrus, ca3 and ca1. Information are processed along those three areas but =
each area returns also feedback to the entorhinal cortex (which in turn con=
nects to the cortex). The hippocampus has been implicated in many different=
 functions (depending on the species in which it is observed) but maybe com=
mon to all problem domains of the species that have a hippocampus is the fa=
ct that it has something to do with sequence learning. <br>
<br></p></div><=
/div></div></div></blockquote><div style=3D"font-size: 22px; ">I'm not deny=
ing there is a lot of sequence/temporal learning out there. I'm just saying=
 that most such problems are complex enough that they also have a lot of sp=
atial parallelism (such as the splitting of the information stream out to t=
he different modules you mention). I just have a hard time imagining a sing=
le-stream, complex, processing machine that learns to do different tasks. B=
ut at this point I'm just wildly speculating. If such a mental structure ex=
isted, would modularity help? By definition, we've eliminated parallel modu=
les. So modularity would have to pay off in terms of a serial sequence of m=
odules. It is interesting to think about whether/why modularity pays off in=
 that case (and if it pays off for that specific organism, or across evolut=
ionary time). </div><div style=3D"font-size: 22px; "><br></div><blockq=
uote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); posi=
tion: static; z-index: auto; "><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position: re=
lative; font-size: 17px; "><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div =
id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>
Given the fact that the anatomy of the hippocampus is =
very well conserved across evolution it seems to me that the hippocampus is=
 an excellent example, that spatial properties of biological neural network=
s can also be exploited to solve temporal problems. Its modular structure s=
eems to play crucial role here.<br>
<br>
For more see: <a href=3D"http://ww=
w.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079">http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1688=
1079</a><br>
<br>
> As such, even if our technique did not encourage mod=
ularity for simple problems where no separate processing streams are requir=
ed, it probably is still important for most (all?) complex problems.  <br>
=
<br>
In this context I was wondering whether it could be helpful to measure=
 the ratio between the current number of edges in a network and the number =
of edges that have to be removed in order to have a modular network. Maybe,=
 this ratio could help to provide an analytical solution for the question h=
ow likely it is that modularity emerges in larger networks. <br>
<br></p></=
div></div></div></div></blockquote><div style=3D"font-size: 22px; ">What wo=
uld that number tell you? How close you are to mutating to a modular networ=
k at any given generation?</div><div style=3D"font-size: 22px; "><br></div>=
<div style=3D"font-size: 22px; ">-Jeff</div><div style=3D"font-size: 22px; =
"><br></div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: r=
gb(255, 255, 255); position: static; z-index: auto; "><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg=
" style=3D"position: relative; font-size: 17px; "><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" styl=
e=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>
Best,<br>
Martin<br>
